subject: Re: [junit] Don't show exception messages to users (was assertTrue(true))
msgSnippet: ... You re _still_ thinking like a programmer... :) Do this instead: if(! ssn.matches(SOCIAL_SECURITY_MASK) ){ throw new InvalidDataException(MESSAGE, ssn); }
messageBody:
Kevin Lawrence wrote:
> Elliotte Harold wrote:
>
>>Kevin Lawrence wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>>>"Social security number should match the pattern 999-99-9999. AB-1234-XY
>>>is not a valid social security number."
>>
>>
>>You're still thinking like a programmer.
>
>
> Actually I was thinking like someone writing a quick example on a
> mailing list.
>
> try this one instead :
>
>
> if(! ssn.matches(SOCIAL_SECURITY_MASK) ){
> throw new InvalidDataException(Messages.format(MESSAGE, ssn));
> }

You're _still_ thinking like a programmer... :)

Do this instead:

if(! ssn.matches(SOCIAL_SECURITY_MASK) ){
throw new InvalidDataException(MESSAGE, ssn);
}

and:
public InvalidDataException extends Exception {
public InvalidDataException(String messageKey, Object ... params) {
super(Messages.format(messageKey, params);
}
}

The point is that if you pass in the pre-constructed message to the
Exception, you're losing information. So don't.

This way, if you want a hard-coded message in the exception (the easy
case), it's the exception's responsibility to do that. _But_ if you want to
do something else, then you can, without changing the thrower of the Exception.

> The exception type communicates to the programmer. Any caller can handle
> the exception if it makes sense to do so.

Yes, but by only providing the string, you've limited their ability to do
so. Consider this:

String[] ssnStrings = ...;
List<SocialSecurityNumber> ssns = new ArrayList<SocialSecurityNumber>();
for (String ssn : ssnStrings ) {
ssns.add(new SocialSecurityNumber(ssn);
}

If you only provide the message, the caller needs to remember which one
they were working on, and provide a user-friendly error message. If you
provide the actual data, then the caller has a lot more options.

The key points are these:
1) It's the responsibility of the class that throws the exception to
provide error information.
2) It's the responsibility of the exception to hold that error information.
3) It's the responsibility of either the exception OR another error
handling object to turn the exception into an error message, using the
supplied information.

And if Oracle had paid attention to these, I wouldn't be getting sick of
seeing "table or view not found" messages...

Robert.
